name: Roman Numerals
description: An additive and subtractive numeral system using letters I, V, X, L, C, D, M.
morphology: Digits are letters; composition is based on additive (e.g., VIII) and subtractive (e.g., IV) patterns.
construction_rules: Write largest symbols first; sometimes place a smaller symbol before a larger one to indicate subtraction.
recursive_logic: Numbers are decomposed into thousands, hundreds, tens, and ones, each expressed with symbol combinations.
cultural_context: Used in ancient Rome; still used today in clocks, book chapters, and event numbering.

name: Mayan Numerals
description: A vigesimal (base-20) system using dots, bars and a shell sign for zero.
morphology: Digits 0‚Äì19 are written with up to four dots and three bars; numbers stack vertically with powers of 20.
construction_rules: Each level in the stack represents a power of 20; top is most significant.
recursive_logic: Numbers are decomposed into coefficients for 20^0, 20^1, 20^2, etc., each shown as a glyph.
cultural_context: Used by the Maya civilization, notable for an early explicit zero symbol.
